result.execSummary:
The defendant Joseph D Brumfield was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possess w/ Intent-THC (>1000-2500 grams) [Modifiers: Second and Subsequent Offense, PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1m)(h)3.
  • Bail Jumping-Felony, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

superMiscConds.notes: Defendant must pay all outstanding fees and court obligations including costs of supervision during the term of supervision.   If supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.  Collections may include income assignment.

No alcohol or controlled substances except by prescription. Random UA's are authorized. Any counseling deemed appropriate by agent; specifically AODA assessment, treatment and after care. DNA sample previously provided, however, defendant must pay mandatory DNA surcharge.  Firearm warning given. Voting is prohibited until sentence is complete and civil rights have been restored. Defendant must obey all rules and regulations while on supervision.

The State indicates Ch. 950 is not applicable to this case. Parties have reviewed both PSI's. No additions or corrections noted by parties. The State recommends in 13CF1092, 3 yrs WPS bifurcated as 18 mos IC, 18 mos ES, 14CF1222, Ct 1-18 mos IC, 30 mos ES, consecutive and on Ct 3 18 mos IC, 18 mos ES-conc.

                             Ct 3-Total sentence is 2 yrs WPS bifurcated as 1 yr IC, 1 yr ES, consec to Ct 1

Defendant Joseph D Brumfield in court with attorney Carolyn Hillery Delery.  Defendant Joseph D Brumfield in custody.  Sharon Ann Riek appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court Reporter: Patricia Schaefer.
The Court has also received a motion to vacate plea agreement due to illegal recommendation. Defense objects as they do not believe the State has jurisdiction to bring said motion. Defense also indicates that the deft wishes to go forward today and he waives any kinds of objections  or problems that may be available to the Court. The State indicates they believe the amended information must be vacated and a new plea agreement made. The State indicates they do not have a new information but rely on the original information.

BTC: The plea agreement was an illegal impossibility. Plea is vacated and parties are to renegotiate.  The dismissal in 14CF1239 is also vacated  Status conference scheduled for May 11, 2015 at 08:30 am.  Bail/bond hearing scheduled for May 1, 2015 at 01:30 pm.

Preliminary hearing on September 11, 2014 at 08:30 am.

Charges per attached criminal complaint. Conditions:  It is a condition of this bond that the defendant NOT consume or possess any controlled substances.  This is to be monitored by random UA's and/or breathalyzers.  The defendant is to report directly to Zimmerman Consulting Inc. (ZCI) for monitoring - report to 524 Main Street, Suite 302, Racine, WI  53403 (third floor of the Monument Square Building) or call (262)632-1780 to immediately schedule an appointment.   The defendant is further ordered to report for testing after each court appearance.   No contact with victim store except for restitution purposes.  Failure to appear will result in the issuance of a warrant for your arrest, possible bail jumping charges and forfeiture of any bond on deposit.
